answers.answer: There are many causes of frequent urination including diabetes mellitus or diabetes insipidus, kidney problems, urinary tract infections and more.  For starters have a urinalysis, and blood work performed.  Don't forget behavioral causes.  Has there been any changes in the environment that could cause a desire for more attention?  Any new additions to the family?

Is he neutered?  Intact males can get enlarged prostates, even infections, that can present with this sort of thing.In any event, he needs a good checkup to rule out problems that could range from prostate trouble, UTI's, or even diabetes.
I will try and collect a urine sample tonight on him.  what am i looking for when testing this urine?  He is neutered.  As for behavioral changes none that I can think of.

Collect the sample as close to the time you will be going to the vet as possible.  All you have to do is hold a plastic cup under the stream.  Also, first morning urine tends to give better results on some tests.  If you can't get the sample to the vet in less than an hour, put it in the refrigerator until you can leave.Urinalysis can tell the vet many different things that might be going on with your dog like infection, blood in the urine, electrolyte levels and more.

question: my dog wakes up several times a night and has to go outside.  this just started here not to long ago and he has never had this problem before.  He is a 3 year old rat terrior and he is taken out every night before bedtime and still needs to usually be taken out at least once a night.  what could be causing this?
title: potty problems
